reviewText: The Scarlet Pimpernel, 1935 filmThe story begins in 1792 London. Soldiers parade to music and commands to entertain the Prince of Wales. The news from Paris tells about fifty people executed by a guillotine (a more humane method than hanging). People cheer the fall of the blade as if they were at a sporting event. The knitting women pause to watch the falling blade. An Englishman helps the aristocrats to flee France. People depart when the show is over. We see prisoners in jail. One aristocrat says they were too detached from reality. A visiting priest offers advice. More prisoners are culled for their last ride in a tumbril. One man is taken off. A traffic jam halts the wagons. One wagon leaves Paris, an old hag has a passport. Later a troop of cavalry leaves in pursuit. The passengers in the coach are safe. Percy gives his friends advice: "Don't get caught!" Their work is becoming dangerous.Chauvelin is sent to search for The Scarlet Pimpernel. The former ambassador is offered a deal: gather information. Lady Marguerite Blakeney poses for her portrait. The rescuers plot to save French aristocrats. Blakeney inspects the portrait. Chauvelin learns things at Dover. Marguerite wants Armand to stay in England. Percy has a complaint about Marguerite. Men watch a bare-knuckle boxing match. [Note the style of fighting.] Armand has been arrested in Boulogne. Chauvelin offers a deal to Marguerite to save Armand. She talks to Percy. Chauvelin is now the French Ambassador. Two prisoners are released so they can be followed (an old, old trick). The news from France says the King is doomed. The French have a spy at this meeting. Chauvelin wants that note. Can Marguerite get it? Clever? The library at midnight is quiet.Marguerite tells Percy about Armand! Why tell him now? What was the deal? Marguerite had a complaint about St.Cyr. She confesses what she did to Percy. Can Percy help her brother? She notices a detail in a painting! Later she gets a letter from Chauvelin. She goes to warn Ffolkes about the danger to Percy. Chauvelin is on guard for Percy now, but Percy is well disguised. One jailer has information for Chauvelin about the planned rescue. Chauvelin arrives at that inn to capture Percy. Will he be successful? Or be surprised? "Is this the last adventure?" Can Marguerite be saved? "Goodbye, my sweet." Percy quotes Shakespeare. A firing squad assembles outside and fires a volley. Will there be a big surprise? And a happy ending for Percy and Marguerite?This 1935 film about danger abroad could echo the European situation at that time. The book was popular before the events of WW II created newer stories about escape from tyranny.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Scarlet PimpernelThis 1935 telling of the classic story has many pluses; first is the cast, with Leslie Howard as Sir Percy Blakeney,  Merle Oberon as Lady Marguerite Blakeney, Raymond Massey as Chauvelin, and Nigel  Bruce as Prince of Wales.  The next is the script, which was adapted from  the novel by Robert E. Sherwood, Sam Berman, Arthur Wimperis, and Lajos  Biro.  Finally, the overall production and look is superb -- while the  story may be short on action, it is strong in character and intrigue.I  do quibble with the tape quality -- it looks as if it was taken from an old  print of the film; there are several scratches and one apparent break;  however, the sound is pretty good.  I hope that one day, the film will be  restored and new audiences will have an opportunity to watch Leslie Howard  and Merle Oberon together in this project.If you are a fan of Leslie  Howard or Merle Oberan, if you are a fan of films from Hollywood's  "Golden Age" or if you simply enjoy the story of the Scarlet  Pimpernel, then add this video to your collection.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I saw today that the remake of THE SCARLET PIMPERNEL starring Jane Seymour and Anthony Andrews is finally coming out on DVD.  Wonderful!But before you buy it and see it and applaud the performances by Seymour and Andrews you must watch the original starring the great Leslie Howard as Sir Percy Blakeney and, as his Lady Blakeney, Merle Oberon because Seymour and Andrews take virtually all of their mannerisms, accents and cues from the original, greater duo.  Raymond Massey also creates the role of the sinister Citizen Chauvelin that Ian McKellen parrots in the newer version.Please don't get me wrong.  The Seymour/Andrews/McKellen version is not poorer in its presentation than the original. It is simply richer for having followed almost completely the standard set by this original version.  It is a statement to the greatness of the original production.This original version is wonderfully classical from its black and white presentation to its script and acting.  THE SCARLET PIMPERNEL tells the story of a robust heroic man who must play the dandy in order to conceal his efforts as a British superhero to save as many as he can from the guillotine during the French Revolution.  In the process he not only saves lives but also ultimately wins the love of his life all over again.THE HORSEMAN

reviewText: This great version of 'The Scarlet Pimpernel' deserves the full Criterion or Anchor Bay treatment -- this Madacy DVD is a disgrace! Murky picture and muddy sound -- skip it and go instead to Amazon's UK site where you can pick up on Region 2 DVD the fantastic 1980s version with Anthony Andrews, Jane Seymour and Ian McKellen. reviewText: Like all movies made from good literature, one misses the parts that are left out. But if you come to this movie without having read the book, it's actually a rather marvelous adventure. Sure, things are changed, but they managed to change them in ways that are, for the most part, plausible. I don't go for the way Lady Blakeney discovered the identity of the Scarlet Pimpernel: too easy for others to have discovered it. But it did save time.Lady Blakeney is played by Merle Oberon, very young and beautiful. Percy is played by Leslie Howard, tall and foppish and quite believable. Cauvelin is played by Raymond Massey, who did evil characters so well when he was young. I didn't recognize any other faces well enough to put names to them.The clever disguises, ruses and tricks are there in abundance, although a few were combined to save time. The beautiful costumes and settings (we are talking about aristocrats here, after all) are there, and used to advantage. The pace is fast enough to satisfy those who have been raised on slam-bang action of the modern movie, but there are enough thoughtful dialogues to offer up some of the subtleties of the story.Why am I not telling you anything of the plot? Because even if you have read the book, the movie is just enough different to keep you guessing. Yes, you know the secret identity of the Pimpernel almost from the beginning, instead of in the middle in the book. But the familiar "he's trapped; how is he going to get out of this" is still there, and I wouldn't spoil it for you for all the world. There's humor and romance and adventure and danger and even historical relevance: what more can anyone ask?
summary: Classic Movie Drawn From a Classic Book

reviewText: Even tho this story is quite old, it still has a lot to say about history and the trials of war and loyalty.  It is fast moving, suspensful and very interesting.  Howard played an unusual role for himself and Oberon was as beautiful and as great as usual. It was really tough living for the poor.I think some folks even today would like to see us go back to this time, with the rich having all the control and the poor, or working class being left behind.  Something for thought.

reviewText: .. don't miss this version ...  Even though most rental and sale copies of this film are based on very poor quality prints, some of the charm of this original will shine through. [There were earlier versions, but not widely distributed].The backgrounds of the leads and the producer lends this version a particular zest, I have always thought.  The writer of the book, Baroness Orczy, was a Hungarian noblewoman who married an Englishman in the late 19th century. The producer Alexander Korda was Hungarian, who came to the UK to make his name in the film business - he also eventually married the star of this film, Merle Oberon (whose origins appear to be Anglo-Indian, or Eurasian).  The other lead, Leslie Howard, was the descendant of Hungarian Jews, or so claim several websites.  This odd melange however put together a production starring that quintessential Englishman (in historical romps, anyway) - Sir Percy Blakeney.For those of you who have not watched the film nor read the story, I will not give away too much of the story.  I should add that this film version is the closest to the original book (important for purists and lovers of the book), except in some small matters such as the reason Marguerite hates a certain French aristocrat.  For me, this version was long the only version I watched or cared to watch, and Leslie Howard *was* Sir Percy Blakeney, the consummate fop.  To many persons he still is.I won't go into raptures about the other great performance - that of Raymond Massey as Chauvelin.  Other reviewers have done fuller justice to his work.  For many people, Merle Oberon is Marguerite, untouched even by Jane Seymour.  For a great viewing experience, I recommend watching the 1934 version, followed by the 1982 version (starring Anthony Andrews and Jane Seymour).  While keeping in mind that the 1982 version combines two novels and takes some liberties with historical chronology and geography, you might find it fruitful to wonder which version will better stand the test of time.I gave this film four stars, for the following reasons: 1) the film is not based on the greatest story in the world (and some scenes frankly irritate me, smacking as they do of 1930s sensibilities, rather than 1790s attitudes and beliefs) 2) the print quality of most VHS editions and the DVD edition is truly horrible.
summary: If you love the Scarlet Pimpernel...

reviewText: A fine movie, it holds up well. This version, starring Leslie Howard, a Hungarian Jew working in films in England, seems to have made a deep impression on Raoul Wallenberg, a  young Swede who saw "The Scarlet Pimpernel" in Stockholm with his sister. Many years later, she said Raoul had liked the film very much and told her that "he'd like to do that, too." Although no one can say for sure that this film was crucial to Wallenberg's character, it may have been.Unlike the Pimpernel, a fictional character who saved French aristocrats from the guillotine, Wallenberg really did save lives. Attached to the Swedish Embassy in Budapest during World War II, Wallenberg saved thousands of Hungarian Jews from the death camps during the Holocaust.
summary: The movie that inspired Raoul Wallenberg

reviewText: There are a few good renditions of this story but I like Leslie Howard & Merle Oberon's the best. Raymond Massey plays the perfect antagonist here.In France heads are rolling as Madame Guillotine removes the aristocracy from power & life. The mere suspicion of being an aristocrat can cost you your life.In England refugees flood in fleeing France & then they must hear the news of their friends that didn't escape France. A Britain known only as the Scarlet Pimpernel has begun to disguise himself as a French peasant & help the ex-rulers to escape the guillotine. His main tool is his wits.The revolutionary leaders don't enjoy their borders being violated, victims snatched from death & looking foolish since they can't catch him. The Pimpernel's wife is French & has apparently caused some people to be fed to the Guillotine.A French diplomat is assigned the task of discovering the Pimpernel's identity & catching him in France where justice will be served. Surprises await the ending of the movie but it's the unexpected roles & great acting that makes this my favorite.The Pimpernel perfect, the wife perfect, the spy perfect & numerous supporting roles are great also. A terrific period piece when that world knew no peace.I like 3 of the Pimpernel's shows but this one is my 5 stars.

reviewText: The inspiration for Zorro, Superman and all the masked heroes who followed.  (Yes there were numerous heroes prior to SP including Sherlock Holmes, Tarzan and Robin Hood but they all operated "in the open" under their real names.)There have been almost 20 Pimpernel productions (counting the 1999 - 2000 BBC series with Richard E. Grant as one series with six episodes).  The 1934 adaptation, although one of the earliest, is most people's favorite.  Producer Alexander Korda did not skimp with sets, costumes or cast.  The script is faithful to the original books.  The cast features Leslie Howard, Raymond Massey, a surprisingly young Nigel Bruce as the Prince of Wales and the incredibly lovely Merle Oberon.Any Pimpernel production will succeed or fail depending on the quality of the three leads: Sir Percy, his wife Marguerite and his nemesis, Chauvelin.  For example, the 1982 TV version had a great Marguerite in Jane Seymour and an exceptional Chauvelin in Ian McKellen.  His interpretation is a highly intelligent man who loves intrigue for its own sake.  Unfortunately, Anthony Andrews' Sir Percy was insufferably boring.  You can't see why anyone would willingly share his company.  I would rate his performance a 3/5.  Or take the BBC version mentioned above.  Much maligned for not adhering to "the canon," Martin Shaw's Chauvelin is cynical and world-weary but understands his world better than most of his peers.  Richard E. Grant's version is my personal favorite, since as both Sir Percy AND the Pimpernel he seems just a tad crazy.  I give him a 5/5.  Unfortunately Elizabeth McGovern's Marguerite is a bit of a limp fish compared to her co-stars.This version features a performance by Leslie Howard that is neither as flamboyant as Grant nor as dull as Andrews but a pleasant contrast to both.  Call it 4/5.  Merle Oberon's Marguerite isn't given enough screen time to garner the sympathy she ought to have (i.e., not explaining the circumstances behind her "betrayal" of the St. Cyr family) but it's a treat just to watch her.  The flaw here is Raymond Massey's Chauvelin who is rather a cartoony villain -- pompous and smug but certainly no intellectual challenge to the Pimpernel.The edition of the film currently on VOD badly needs restoration, not only to eliminate scratches, etc. but to reinstate missing frames to make it less "jumpy."

reviewText: The Scarlet Pimpernel was taken from a 1903 play. It made its film debut in 1917 and there were a total of 4 Pimpernel silent films. Leslie Howard stars, supported by Merle Oberon and Raymond Massey, in this 1934 Alexander Korda production, the first of the talking Pimpernel films.The rich man with a secret crime fighting life was copied by characters like Zorro, Batman, The Phantom, and Green Arrow.  The Pimpernel has no super powers, but survives on his cunning and bravery, as well as a small group of supporters who keep his secret.In his brief career and 34 films Leslie Howard (1893-1943) was twice nominated for an Oscar ("Berkeley Square" and "Pygmalion") and gave us memorable performances in "GWTW" (1939) and "The Petrified Forest" (1936). He started in films in the U.K. in 1914 and came to the U.S. in 1930. His big breakthrough came in 1933 with "Berkeley Square" and his great performance in this film helped secure his stardom.Merle Oberon (1911-79) started in films in 1928 but it was her role as Anne Boleyn opposite Charles Laughton in "The Private Life of Henry VIII" (1933) that brought her to stardom, and like Howard, her follow-up in this film helped move her to the A list where she stayed for more than a decade. She was nominated for an Oscar for "The Dark Angel" (1935) but is probably best remembered for her role as Cathy in "Wuthering Heights" (1938). She plays the Pimpernel's wife.The great Raymond Massey (1896-1983) is best remembered for his roles as Lincoln. He was nominated for an Oscar for playing "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" (1940) which remains, to date, the best ever portrayal of Lincoln. He reprised the role on TV in "The Day Lincoln was Shot" (1950) and again in "How the West Was Won" (1962). On TV he played Dr. Gillespie in the series "Dr Kildare" (1961-5). He made nearly 100 films. I remember him best for his over the top portrayal of John Brown in "Santa Fe Trail" (1940). Massey plays the evil  Citizen Chauvelin. Prior to playing Lincoln, most of his roles were villainous (e.g., Philip of Spain in "Fire Over England", Black Michael in "The Prisoner of Zenda", Prince Ghul in "The Drum").Nigel Bruce (1895-1953) has a small role as The Prince of Wales. Bruce is best remembered for his role as Dr. Watson in 14 Sherlock Holmes films, but he had quite a distinguished career apart from the Holmes' film, appearing in many films like "Treasure Island" (1934), "Charge of the Light Brigade" (1936), and "Kidnapped" (1938). He worked with Hitchcock in "Rebecca" (1940) and "Suspicion" (1941).If I'm not mistaken, a very young James Mason (1909-84) has a small speaking part near the start of the movie. He did work with Korda and he did appear in "Return of the Scarlet Pimpernel" (1937)  but his appearance in this film is otherwise un recorded.Alexander Korda (1893-1956) produced nearly 60 films in his career that started in 1923 in Hungary. His break through film was "The Private Life of Henry VIII" (1933) and there followed a series of historical dramas including "Rise of Catherine the Great" (1934), "Private Life of Don Juan" (1934), and "Rembrandt" (1936).The costumes are lavish but the sets are relatively cheap. Painted backdrops are obvious and the outdoor scenes appear to be filmed in Los Angeles scrub rather than the French countryside.Harold Rosson (1895-1988) was the cinematographer. Rosson filmed nearly 150 films and was nominated for an Oscar 6 times, winning for "The Garden of Allah" (1937). He made such notable films as "The Wizard of Oz" (1939), "30 Seconds Over Tokyo" (1944), and "The Asphalt Jungle" (1950). Rosson turns in his usual fine job, offering varying angles and a plethora of long, medium, and close-ups. His action scenes with horses chasing a carriage are particularly good for the time.This is a better than average period piece and may be one of Leslie Howard's best performances.

reviewText: They seek him here.They seek him there.Those Frenchies seek him everywhere.Is he in heaven?Is he in hell?That demmed elusive PimpernelBased on the novel by Baroness Emmuska OrczySir Percy Blakeney (Leslie Howard) is an English aristocrat leading a double life, by day he's an effete aristocrat and by night he's the Scarlet Pimpernel, rescuing French nobles from the clutches of the French revolution under Robespierre's Reign of Terror.This film was made when talking films first hit the scene and considering it's newness, the era it was made it is a classic in the swashbuckler genera and was one of the first stories that sets the stage for masked vigilantes such as the Batman.Leslie Howard shine a the foppish Sir Percy while donning the guise of the Scarlet Pimpernel rescuing nobles the national razor. This is an instant classic and a shining example of great film work from a fledgling medium.
summary: classic swashbuckling action..set's the stage for the masked vigilante

reviewText: The French Revolution is underway and aristocrats are en route to Madame Guillotine; they have but one hope, and it is the mysterious Englishman known as "The Scarlet Pimpernel," a master of disguise with nerves of steel, a man who swoops in to carry off audacious rescues under the very noses of the executioners.  But just who is that "demmed" Pimpernel?He's Leslie Howard, that's who, enjoying one of the most popular roles of his career alongside the lovely Merle Oberon and with a supporting cast that includes such notables as Raymond Massey and Nigel Bruce.  And so popular was this 1934 English-made film that it did the unthinkable: it challenged Hollywood on its own turf, becoming so successful in the United States that it propelled all four stars and director Harold Young to significant careers in the American film industry.Originally written for the British stage in 1905 and then transformed into a novel by the Hungarian-born author Baroness Orczy (1865-1947), the plot owes at least a little to Charles Dickens' celebrated A TALE OF TWO CITIES--but the Baroness gave it her own spin, and the Scarlet Pimpernel is often cited as the first in a long line of "masked avengers" that would include such characters as Zorro; literary historians also note that there is a direct line of descent from the Pimpernel to such super-spy characters as Ian Flemming's James Bond.  But however you look at it, the thing is good old fashioned, if occasionally creaky, fun.Although he is best remembered for his role in GONE WITH THE WIND, Leslie Howard gives his signature performance as Sir Percy Blakeney--ridiculously foppish in English society yet secretly the daring Scarlet Pimpernel.  Howard aside, the entire cast acquits itself extremely well, with the role of Sir Percy's wife Margarite proving a break-out for Merle Oberon and paving her way to the role of Cathy in the legendary WUTHERING HEIGHTS.  Raymond Massey takes his place among the great screen villains of the 1930s as Chauvelin, determined to expose and destroy Sir Percy, and Nigel Bruce is as charming as always as the Prince of Wales.All in all, this is easily the best of several screen versions of THE SCARLET PIMPERNEL.  Unfortunately, it is also virtually impossible to find a decent print of the film.  Like several very famous films of the 1930s and 1940s, it has slipped into public domain--and the result is a bunch of home-market releases that offer fuzzy picture and lousy sound.  The widely available Madacy and Digiview releases are truly atrocious.  Perhaps one day the film will receive restoration and a decent DVD release--but until then you're better off looking for it on the late-late show, for I can guarantee that the broadcast prints are likely to be better than what you'll find on DVD.GFT, Amazon Reviewer

reviewText: This early version of the Baroness' 19th Century novel is the best Saturday afternoon diversion, as a novel or film. Leslie Howard plays Sir Percy with incredible chameleon-like ease, the English nobleman who spares French citizens with heroics and deceptions, the greatest to his lovely wife, Merle Oberon, who wants a man back in the home, not a fop.(how modern!)Raymond Massey is absolutely devilish up to his neck in deceit. You want a yarn well-told, this is it. The costuming and protocol are perfect.This is what a countryman does when his diplomacy fails (you hear that Washington?).

reviewText: This first film version of Baroness Orcy's story is excellent. Leslie Howard (known for his turn as Ashley Wilkes in "Gone With The Wind") does a heroic job playing two roles. (He could certainly act). One minute, he's a brainless aristocrat with a devil-may-care attitude, constantly messing up people's names, and the next, he's The Scarlet Pimpernel. Quite the acting chops, I dare say. Merle Oberon is terrific as Marguerite St. Juste and Raymond Massey is pure menace as Citizen Chauvelin. My only complaint is that there wasn't a swordfight at the end between Sir Percy & Chauvelin. Rumour has it that The Scarlet Pimpernel inspired another dashing hero...the masked avenger ZORRO.
summary: "They Seek Him Here, They Seek Him There, Those Frenchies Seek Him Everywhere..." Marvelous Acting By Leslie Howard.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Leslie Howard is the courageous English aristocrat who saves French aristocrats from the guillotine in this filming of the famous novel.  Very few know just who this mysterious saviour, the "Scarlet Pimpernel", really is, since he uses disguises and moves with the secrecy of a spy.  Howard must also keeps his double life secret from his wife, Merle Oberon, a woman he loves but does not like very much.  But forces are conspiring against him to reveal the truth about the Scarlet Pimpernel, which would lead to the brutal deaths of so many Frenchmen.  Howard plays the many faces of his character with equal class and wit, giving a very natural and relaxed performance that is among the best I've ever seen him give.  Oberon also scores well, getting more out of her character than simply being a very beautiful decoration in the film.  The film could use a little more action, and unfortunately the years have not been good to the quality of the film's prints (especially the sound), but there is a lot here to entertain anyways.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The 1934 offering we bought was released in December, 2008, by Reel Classics.  So, we had hopes that defects reported earlier had been cured.  Apparently, though, this "restoration" was done for widescreen applications as the video was severely letter-boxed.  We don't own a widescreen TV, so maybe it's unfair to evaluate.  Nevertheless, we regard video and sound as poor and there were no subtitles, chapters, or special features.  The disk would not play on our trusty Philips 711 player so we had to figure running time on our newer Panasonic.  It came to a sparse 1 hour, 36 minutes.  The whole story would have been unintelligible had we not read the book or seen the 1982 version of the story beforehand.  Sadly, we have trouble even giving this DVD a single star.

reviewText: If you're looking for a DVD of the Leslie Howard/Merle Oberon version of _The Scarlet Pimpernel_, buy _Drama Classics Triple Feature, Vol. 2_ (The Black Pirate / The Scarlet Pimpernel / The Iron Mask) from Navarre Corporation.This one chops lines and even entire scenes out of the movie. The one on the triple-feature DVD is all there, and the transfer is better too. ('Better', not 'good'. This film is badly in need of restoration.) And the extra two bucks gets you a pair of Doug Fairbanks features into the bargain. (And if _that's_ not a good enough deal for you, the film is also included in _50 Movie Family Classics_.)It's beyond me why anyone would release this classic swashbuckler in such a hacked-up edition. But it's even further beyond me why anybody would _buy_ it while there's a better version available. That damned elusive Pimpernel isn't _that_ hard to find!

reviewText: Wonderful film! Leslie Howard was perfect for the role and played it amusingly well. Very recommended. However, my review is for the DVD release: I wouldn't complain but I've definitely seen it in much better condition on TCM and archives. The one I purchased -- 2007 (Synergy Ent) version -- is not it. Through most of the film it's dark and fuzzy, and there's a bit of feedback on the audio. I would suggest searching for another version, personally; but if you get this one, don't say you weren't warned... This film is definitely a must-own classic, so it would be worth it to get the best available. It's out there somewhere.

reviewText: It's 1792.  The French Revolution trundles along the road to terror - for many an aristocrat and their families, it ends at the guillotine.  To the great annoyance of Citizen Robespierre, the Scarlet Pimpernel has been cheating Madam guillotine of her full quota.  He directs ambassador Chauvelin to return to London and exterminate this pest . . . .If you are Sir Percy  Blakeney, you were in Paris when the madness began, witnessed a Marquis and his family be the first to be guillotined.  Appalled, you had returned to London, gathered a small band of like-minded gents to secretly begin rescue forays as "The Scarlet Pimpernel."  Unhappily, you can't let your French wife learn of your exploits . . . .If you are Lady Marguerite Blakeney, you love Percy with all your heart, but something has come between you;  he seems so distant.  When you married him - he was a man to look up to;  these days, he acts like a silly jack-a-napes;  what happened?  You feel so lonely, but thankfully your dear brother Armand is coming to visit . . . .If you are Monsieur Chauvelin, you see your chance to discover the identity of the Pimpernel when your spies intercept Armand's note to Andrews ... could Andrews be the Pimpernel?  Then it dawns on you - Armand is Marguerite's brother!  She is well connected in London society, and now that you hold her brother, she'll have to help you find the elusive Scarlet Pimpernel . . . .Warning:  You won't be able to get Percy's poem out of your head - it begins: "They seek him here,  they seek him there,  ...."DVD - 2007.  Others have commented on the film's worn condition, however, it is watchable.  Subtitles: none.

reviewText: There is no way to film Baroness Orczy's THE SCARLET PIMPERNAL without its being a costume drama of a bloody period in French history. However, director Robert Sherwood chose to play down the sanguinary aspects of Orczy's novel and play up the drama in the surface foppishness of Sir Percy Blakeney (Leslie Howard), who led the double life of a masked crusader who freed innocent French citizens from the bite of Madame Guillotine. Howard's interpretation of Sir Percy brings to mind his own screen persona in which he plays the poet/philosopher of all his films. Here, Sir Percy is erudite, witty, and not a little bit foppish, all of which he uses as a cover to hide his alter ego from all, even from his wife Marguerite (Merle Oberon), whose own noble French background marks her and her family as candidates for the blade.Sir Percy spends much of the film in a battle of wits with French ambassador Chauvelin (Raymond Massey), who has orders to bring the Scarlet Pimpernal to face French justice or lose his own head. Both men attend lavish ballroom parties in England, spend considerable time together swapping social pleasantries, and generally build suspense as to when Chauvelin will catch the prey who is right under his nose. The action soon switches to France, where Sir Percy goes to free his wife's brother from a date with Robespierre's Committee for Public Safety. Even when Marguerite unexpectedly follows Sir Percy to Paris, does he not fail to evince the suave panache and verve that marks his interpretation of the Pimpernal.One might be tempted to view Sir Percy as nothing more than a dandefied Clark Kent, but to place an equal sign between the two would be lose sight that though the titular hero is the Scarlet Pimpernal, the actual hero is Sir Percy, who uses his wit and charm to save the day. Indeed, this film is so lacking in the Error Flynn type swashbuckling, that to expect more screen time for a masked crusader is to devalue what that wit and charm can accomplish in the hands of a man who knows that words used as pointed barbs can effect far more than those same barbs used as edged weapons. THE SCARLET PIMPERNAL is a wonderful cinematic exploration of how a battle of wits can enthrall an audience to an extent that a costumed crusader could never do.

reviewText: This a wonderful film with the finest actors of the time.  Cloak and dagger excitement where little is as it appears to be. The great Leslie Howard at the top of his game (when wasn't he?) -- Merle Obreon at the height of her beauty and charm and Raymond Massey who could play the bad guy to the hilt.  Set in England and France at the time after the French Revolution when the new government was cruelly beheading everyone for little or no reason.  Taking on the persona of the "Scarlett Pimpernel" with the scatterbrained, foppish wastrel as cover, the wonderful Leslie Howard goes into France on dangerous missions to rescue worthy people falsely accused.  Sure that the beautiful wife he once adored was involved in friends being beheaded, he turns from her.  She is innocent and is desperate to win over her once beloved husband.  She is also half in love with the Scarlett Pimpernel, who she doesn't realize is her husband.  Raymond Massey is superb as the man who vows to end the Scarlett Pimpernel's rescue operation for good.

reviewText: The hero of the story pretends to be a fop, a sissy, so his enemies will not suspect him of being the clever hero he really is. Young English noblemen risk their lives to cleverly save innocent French men and women from death by the guillotine, during the French Revolution of 1792.I don't think anyone could play the charming hero better than Leslie Howard, co-star in "Gone with the Wind"; and a secret agent in real-life in World War II. It is an excellent story, so other versions are likely good too. The beautiful actress Merle Oberon co-stars. Humor, wit, cleverness, romance, heroes, villains, and adventure.This copy could have been copied better; but is acceptable. This film is available from Turner Classic Movies, TCM dot com, for $9. I do not know whether it is a different & better print; same cover picture.Scarlet Pimpernel also a small wild-flower which grows beside the country lanes of England, whose flower opens and closes with the weather, staying open only in sunny weather. The plant was used for medicines in ancient times.Other good period, adventure movies are "Tom Brown's School Days 1935", "David Copperfield 1940 & 2000", "Oliver Twist", "At Swords Point 1952", "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer 1939", "The Three Musketeers 1939" with Don Ameche, and "The Prince and the Pauper 1937 & 2001".

reviewText: I love this movie. Everyone thinks the foppish Sir Percy is nothing more than a twit. Secretly though Sir Percy uses the guise of "the fop" to cover his astounding genious. Beneath his exterior of stupidity, he is really The Scarlet Pimpernel, an English hero who sneaks into Revolutionary France and saves aristos from execution. Not even his own wife knows his secret identity, so when her brother's life is ransomed against her finding and revealing the Pimpernel to the French government, she does not know she will be betraying her husband. Once she discovers the pimpernels identity it is too late to stop her plan to save her brother. Full of love and regret she goes off to warn or if need be die with her love in France. Of course they escape. . . but if I told you how I'd ruin the movie so I wont.You may want to have some foreknowledge about the pimpernel before you watch this. It helps with the plot. Other than that, enjoy!Viva la Frace! Viva la Scarlet Pimpernell!

reviewText: This is not a review of the film, but of the DVD.  All of the DVDs I have seen of this classic look like they have been duped from an eighth-generation copy. At one time, I had the Samuel Goldwyn-issued Laserdisc (which was superb) so I know that a quality print exits out there somewhere.  Maybe in the Korda or Goldwyn vaults?  Come on, guys, shake it loose!  Until that happens, we will have to be satisfied with the 1981 version starring Anthony Andrews, Jane Seymour and Sir Ian McKellan.  That is the best quality version currently available.

reviewText: I would have liked this movie had I not read the book first.  But once you read the book, you realize that this movie is a VERY poor adaption.  The movie unfolds very slowly, is very choppy, and is over too soon, cutting out the most exciting part of the book....the ending.  Sir Percy Blakeney is lovable in the book.  He's complex and funny (clearly not as dumb as he seems), providing a lot of the book's comic relief.  But the script does him no justice, and neither does Leslie Howard, who is clearly (from his first scene to the last shot of the film) too bland (and too thin if you ask me) for the role...and I say that as a big fan of his.  At times he seems almost embarrassed that he even took the part.  Marguerite was also a character who was done no justice by the script.  She spends most of the movie sitting there and complaining....where as in the book, she's another three dimensional character that you understood and sympathized with.  The relationship between Marguerite and Percy is also a complex one that is described beautifully in the book.  There was a particular part in the book that makes it just as much a romance as an adventure, and it was completely left out of the movie.  I was crushed because it was the one moment where you could actually feel the longing between the two of them, and it gave you a glimpse as to what type of man Percy was when it came to his wife.  But the movie barely touches on this relationship.  I couldn't, for the life of me, figure out why these two were even together.  Everyone in the film seems embarrassed by the project, and I can't say I blame them.  The book is fantastic, and this film is probably as shoddy as it can get when it comes to the Scarlet Pimpernel.My Point: It was a HUGE disappointment.
